Award.AwardTitle: Procedures for the Rapid Documentation of Language Acquisition in an Endangered Language Context

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our current understanding of the fundamental human ability to acquire a language with little prompting or conscious learning is based primarily on large languages with robust speech communities. Research has shown that a speaker community providing a rich speech environment where language is used for a variety of social functions provides the input necessary for a child to acquire a language. However, there is little research on how endangered languages are acquired. What is the order of acquisition, in terms of complexity of sounds, phrases, and sentences, when there is lack of robust and varied input? What types of systematic errors do children make and are these errors reflective of an ongoing internal rule-governed grammatical system? Data from endangered languages are crucial in answering these questions and this evidence must be gathered immediately since there are few small languages where intergenerational transmission is still occurring.

Clifton Pye of the University of Kansas will work with an international team to document the acquisition of Northern Pame, an Otomanguean language spoken by approximately 5,000 people in the state of San Luis Potosi, Mexico. Children only speak Northern Pame in two of the seven principal Northern Pame villages, and even in these communities school-age children frequently use Spanish at home. Pye and his team, working with Pame assistants to transcribe and translate Pame child speech, will use a prototype procedure for the rapid documentation of the acquisition of endangered languages. The project will include the training of graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Kansas in language documentation and data archiving methodology. All the data collected will be accessible through the Archive of the Indigenous Languages of Latin America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principle goal of the project was to record and archive a longitudinal sample of children acquiring the Otomanguean language Xi?iuy (Northern Pame). We recorded a total of 174 hours of recordings with 22 children between the ages of one year seven months and four years of age. We have made longitudinal recordings with 3 children over a span of 6 months, and with 1 child over a span of one year. We have transcriptions for 170 of these recordings for children in the different age groups. We archived copies of the recordings and their transcriptions at the Archive of Indigenous Languages of the Americas (AILLA) at the University of Texas, Austin.

Findings

A secondary goal of the project was to test procedures for the rapid documentation of language acquisition. The transcription phase of any language documentation project consumes the most time, and this is of special concern when documenting the acquisition of endangered languages as there will not be many native speakers who have the skill to transcribe their language and have the time to do so. We were fortunate in locating two Xi?iuy speakers to assist in the transcription phase: F?lix Baltazar Hern?ndez and Constantino G?mez Gonz?lez.

In order to facilitate the transcription process, we focused on transcribing the children?s utterances with their adult interpretations and Spanish translations. F?lix and Constantino?s interpretations of the children?s utterances incorporate their experience in hearing child Xi?iuy as well as their background knowledge of the Xi?iuy language and culture. We did not add additional codes for morpheme glosses or discourse features to the transcriptions because these would slow the primary objective of transcribing as many of the recordings as possible in the limited time available. This decision resulted in establishing a clear demarcation between the transcription and analysis phases of the project. We used the ELAN transcription program in order to link the transcriptions with the audio and video recordings. 

In the absence of coding the transcriptions, we invented a procedure for rapidly analyzing the children?s productions. We export the Elan transcription to a tab-delimited text file, which we then import to an Excel worksheet. This process transfers each field in the Elan file to a separate column in the Excel file making it possible to easily extract the utterances for each individual in the recordings. We then run the utterances through a concordance routine that extracts each word and lists the contexts in which each speaker uses the word. The children?s concordances match their productions of each word to its adult target, the Spanish translation, and the time of utterance.

The resulting datasets serve as the basis for analyses of the children?s vocabulary, phonology, morphology and syntax. We have made exploratory analyses in each of these areas and found many surprising results. Due to a long contact with Nahuatl and Spanish, the vocabulary of the adults and children contain words from these two languages. The words from Nahualt and Spanish have been assimilated into the phonological grammar of Pame to different degrees to the extent that it is not possible to draw a clear distinction between the origins of the words in Pame. We made a rough division between the Pame and Spanish vocabulary in the children?s speech in order to assess the degree to which the children evidenced different grammars in the production of Pame and Spanish words. We found evidence for such differences in the structure of their lexicon, their phonology and their morphology.

Pame children produce more verbs than nouns in Pame and more nouns than verbs in Spanish. This result disproves proposals that cognitive constraints limit children?s verb production. There are complications to this story, which we are in the process of investigating. One possibility is that the parents use Pame and Spanish differently in their interactions with the children, which might result in the preferential use of Spanish for naming objects in books. We will know more about the children?s lexicon once we analyze more data. The comparison with Spanish yielded one surprise. Pame speakers occasionally insert the Spanish copula ser into their Pame sentences, often in questions. Pame does not have a copula verb so the use of the Spanish copula appears to fill a gap in the Pame grammar. There is evidence that the Spanish copula serves a different function in Pame. Pame speakers do not change from /es/ to /son/ in plural contexts.

One important lesson from our project is the realization that archiving such an extensive video record is a challenge. Existing archives are set up largely for the purpose of archiving textual material rather than longitudinal video recordings which provide the primary data for research on language acquisition. Institutional support for the long-term preservation of large datasets will be a challenge for language documentation projects of this nature.
